headline: Chef John's Nashville Hot Chicken
description: This Nashville hot chicken recipe featuring ultra-crispy fiery fried chicken with a spicy glaze is one of the most amazing fried chicken dishes you will ever taste!

video.description: Double crispy and full of spicy Southern heat!
video.name: Nashville Hot Chicken

name: Chef John's Nashville Hot Chicken
recipeIngredient: 1 cup vegetable oil for frying, or as needed

recipeInstructions.text: Arrange chicken pieces in a large bowl.

Whisk buttermilk, pickle brine, hot sauce, and egg together in a mixing bowl. Pour marinade over chicken and stir to ensure each piece is thoroughly coated. Cover and let chicken marinate in refrigerator 2 to 4 hours.

Mix flour and salt together in a shallow flat dish. Remove chicken from marinade and blot with paper towels. Reserve marinade. Toss chicken in flour until thoroughly coated. Return chicken to marinade, coating all sides; remove chicken from marinade allowing excess to drip back into the bowl. Coat the chicken once again in flour mixture. Place on a rack. Repeat with all chicken pieces. Allow to sit out about 15 minutes to allow coating to dry out a bit.

Place butter and lard in a large pot. Add cayenne pepper, brown sugar, paprika, garlic powder, kosher salt, and black pepper. Place over medium-high heat. Cook and stir until fats melt. Remove from heat; keep sauce warm.

Fill cast iron skillet about 1/3 of the way with vegetable oil. Heat oil to 350 degrees F over medium-high heat. Carefully place chicken into hot oil, skin side down. Maintain an oil temperature of 325 degrees F, adjusting heat as need. Fry until instant read thermometer reads 160 degrees F, 8 to 10 minutes per side.
Transfer chicken to a rack to drain. Brush with the sauce on both sides.

review.reviewBody: I like it, but it seems like there should be a touch of acid somewhere, like a little vinegar or citrus?

Loved the recipe. I adapted it to be vegan with seitan and milk/fat substitutes, and it still created a wonderfully crispy breading. My only dislike was that I thought the sauce could use some tweaking to really hit a Nashville Hot level of spice and flavor.

Okay , but skip the lard , skip the sugar and add One tablespoon of Worcestershire sauce and Three tablespoons of Frank’s Red Hot and call it Buffalo Chicken ( skip the pickles entirely) … remember , every winning team in the NFL has “Buffalo Wings “ on the training table …you’ll win with your family & friends with Buffalo Chicken !!!

Great Flavor. I did add two tablespoons of honey along with some chipotle and ancho chili powders. Along with two tablespoons of smoked paprika for depth. it was awesome! serviced with pickled onions, pickles, and some garlic aioli on a Hawaiian slider roll!

Chef John, love your recipes! For the folks who had trouble with the sauce breaking, you can substitute honey for the brown sugar or even corn syrup in a pinch. I found that heating the sauce very gently prevented it from breaking.
Didn't use lard.. all butter. Topped on a homemade waffle. Yum!
Loves this recipe. Have made it many times. I add fresh garlic to the oil and let simmer on a very low heat for 45 minutes to a hour.

This hands down is the best nashville hot sauce recipe you can get your hands on. Im still in disbelief on how good it is. So simple but unbelievably good I added a pinch extra of table salt but then again I am a salt guy. I'm excited to make this for someone.
Shatteringly crisp skin and moist delicious meat! A huge hit!

We love this recipe at our house. After making it several times I added 1tsp. Knorr chicken boullion and 1/2 tsp. dry mustard to the spices in the oil. Perfection! If we are on a time crunch we've even cheated and bought Raising Kanes chicken stips and just made the seasoned oil mix and dipped the whole strips in there. It's great too all though not exact a good quick meal for a week night.

Great recipe. I don't like deep fat frying so when I got to the last step I substituted panko bread crumbs mixed with oil for the second flour dredge and then put them on a rack on a baking sheet and put them on an upper oven rack and cooked at 400 degrees using the convection roast setting so the broiler element would cycle on as well as the bottom element. They were done in about 25 minutes and lightly browned on top, but no browning on the bottom. Next time I will use the broiler setting briefly and flip them over to brown both sides.
It’s sooo good ! My son’s favorite. This was our second time and it’s better each time .
Just used the sauce recipe to make sandwiches. I had bought fried chicken already. Absolutely delish! Spice builds as you eat it. Perfect with barefoot contessa’s Mephis coleslaw

thank you very much
it's very good
but the sauceis separates

So good! I seasoned the flour to add extra flavor and didn’t use lard for the sauce-just butter. I also added hot honey to the sauce and it was sooo good! 10/10 recommend. I may try to make the recipe into a chicken sandwich with pickles

This recipe is a good one. The best I've found on this site so far. Not quite hot enough and who's to say if it's the recipe's fault or my own, but it wasn't as great as I hoped. Still worth trying if you're looking to make some Nashville chicken.
Delish!!!! Sweet heat!!!!
The best fried chicken I've ever made. The pickle juice in the marinade is sublime ??
This was the best fried chicken I’ve ever had! Great flavor, super moist, and finger licking good! It’s really not as spicy as I expected and in a good way!

Mine didn't turn out as well as I'd hoped... I followed the directions to the letter. I had to borrow my parent's fryer for the last step. It burned pretty much immediately. I don't blame the recipe-- I blame the old fryer I had to literally hold in place. 
Thank God it had a lid, so I wasn't burned. The chicken tasted good, though. And I don't fault the recipe for my failure as a chef.
I fault the old fryer .
The family liked it. This will be one of my go to chicken recipes.

I made this for the first time tonight and this recipe is AMAZING. I used a pack of 12 chicken legs and doubled the ingredients. The glaze did separate but I tossed the chicken in it before serving and it worked out perfectly. Served with homemade Mac and cheese, buttermilk biscuits, and honey glazed peas- perfect! Thank you for the amazing recipe.

The chicken had a delicious mildly hot flavor. I did have a hard time keeping the oil at 325 degrees but I never really fry things so I’ll need some more experience with that. I did modify the recipe by doubling the hot sauce in the marinade as well as the cayenne pepper to the sauce. I also added some of the marinade to the flour to make flour chunks stick to the chicken. I loved how crunchy and tasty it was. I will leave this recipe in my book. 
Note: I did use Nashville Hot Chicken seasoning in the flour. Even after all the modifications in an attempt to make it hot, the chicken was still mild. Will probably up my cayenne pepper or add habanero in the future.
Really good. I used boneless skinless chicken thighs because that’s what I had on hand, and I added some of my hot fry oil to the sauce spices instead of butter/lard. Thanks for the yummy recipe!

I used whole milk for the marinade, rather than buttermilk, and an extra tablespoon of cayenne for the sauce. It was delicious and almost tear-inducing.

Do not skip the lard, in my first attempt I tried to make the sauce with just butter and the sugar congealed into lumps. (and lard tastes great, totally underrated ingredient in American cuisine)

I also recommend dipping the chicken into the sauce before serving, rather than brushing.
Easiest and most delicious fried chicken in the world. I added an extra TBS of cayenne to amp up the heat. Must use LARD! Keep the breading nice and crispy.

This is the BEST fried chicken I have ever made in 40 years of my life, so much so that I created an account here just to drop a review. I followed all instructions except I did not blot the marinated chicken before the first breading (I missed that part), I used chicken breasts cut into roughly 1inch x 2inches and I used all-butter for the glaze. Soooooo delicious, and 0 regrets! Thank you Chef John

Made this using our air fryer and turned out great! Used 1.5 TB of cayenne for the oil, and gluten free flour for my mother, and it was still very spicy and delicious. Anyone looking to try with an air fryer, we did 390 degrees for 25 min, turning the chicken at 13 min and applying oil/butter to the dry floury parts. Soooo delicious!

Me and my family really liked the flavor of this chicken. Instead of whole cut up chicken, I used tenders, since this was what I had on hand. Will definitely make this again! It went well with homemade coleslaw and potatoe wedges
I added the spice mixture to the flour and then also to the lard/butter mixture. So basically twice the spices. Soooooo good

This was my first time making Nashville Hot Chicken and it was amazing! I used boneless skinless chicken breasts since that’s what I had on hand. I made sandwiches and then topped them with pickles and coleslaw. I will use this recipe again! I also loved the perfectly portioned ingredients. No waste!

I loved this recipe. It was the second time I made it and while delicious, I found the sauce a little “wimpy” the fist time so on the second try I added more Cayenne pepper and less brown sugar. I also added a habenero which made it amazing!?
Wow! This was soooo flavorful! My husband and I loved it!
Really crispy chicken and not very spicy at all. I just used the fry oil and skipped the butter/lard. Will certainly make again.
Best recipe for Nashville style fried chicken
This made a great hot chicken sandwhich with pepper jack cheese and bread and butter pickles, along with excellent hot wings. Awesome recipe from the best Chef on YouTube.
Great recipe spot on.
This is great, thanks John.

I made this tonight because the grocery store had chicken legs on sale. I decided to make half of them this recipe and half of them Chef Johns buttermilk fried chicken (check over there for that review). I really liked this recipe and made no changes to it. I tasted the sauce alone, and it tasted wayyyy too hot. However, once on the chicken, it had the perfect amount of spice. Still, you have to like hot chicken. If you don't even like hot food, I'm not sure why you're reading a hot chicken recipe in the first place. Anyways, the recipe was great. I tried it without putting the sauce on it and you can taste the hot sauce that you marinaded it in, it was good that way too. Next time I'm going to try doing this recipe with chicken tenders, to change things up a bit. I would 10/10 recommend this recipe if you're craving something hot. We have a hot chicken restaurant down the street and it's even better than their Nashville hot chicken. Great recipe!

So good. Sweet but yet spicy. Crispy chicken. Great flavor. It was a slow heat. I made recipe as it called but next time I would cut sauce recipe in half. I fried up 3lbs of chicken and threw a lot of the sauce away. It was a slow heat so I would also go a little lighter on the cayenne next time. Our temperature preference is medium and I’d say the recipe is a medium hot.

So good. Sweet but yet spicy. Crispy chicken. Great flavor. It was a slow heat. I made recipe as it called but next time I would cut sauce recipe in half. I fried up 3lbs of chicken and threw a lot of the sauce away. It was a slow heat so I would also go a little lighter on the cayenne next time. Our temperature preference is medium and I’d say the recipe is a medium hot.
this recipe just wasnt my style after i got done i had the thought " if i had baked this in the oven with salt it would have tasted better" and took 8 hours less
Delicious! One of our favorites!
I've been making Nashville Hot Chicken for years. But then I tried this recipe and realized I wasn't doing it justice! Perfect amount of everything - except we load it up with pickles!
Delicious!

Fantastic! I made it with boneless/ skinless thighs. Instead of frying the chicken, I browned it in a hot pan in a little canola oil for about 5 minutes per side, then baked it at 350 for 20 minutes. I coated the pieces in the sauce and baked for another 5 minutes. I served the chicken on bakery rolls with sliced pickles. No other condiments we needed... the combination of the chicken and pickles was absolutely delicious!

This is definitely a go to for fried chicken! Next time I will marinate overnight (I only did 2 hours this time). I will also use more hot sauce and cayenne pepper! Did not taste like the hot chicken we recently had while driving through Nashville, but it was just as crispy and tender. Thanks for the recipe!
Awesome. Amazing zing...so juicy and flavorful!

Note to self... and anyone else. Don’t sub butter if you dont have clarified butter and don’t skip the lard. My sauce tasted amazing... unfortunately the spices never bound to it and it separated badly. Also like many have said, wait until the very end to make the sauce and don’t let it stand for long. The next time i make this, i am going to use my deep fryer, because it I found it difficult to maintain the correct oil temp in a cast iron. It also made a huge mess. All that said, it was the cook, not the food that was wrong here... it was delicious.
I've never eaten it in Nashville, but this is a really good fried chicken recipe even if you don't brush it with the Kosher lard death nectar. LOL

This was honestly the best thing by FAR I have made from All Recipes! As I love strong, spicy, flavors, I doused the chicken in the sauce. My wife, however, only likes it in small doses so she sprinkled it over hers. We were both SO impressed. My daughter, who doesn't like spicy stuff, had the breaded chicken by itself and could not believe I had actually made it as it was restaurant quality. I can't wait to bring the chicken strips, with a cautionary warning, to the next event we attend!

I used a deep fryer for 10 thighs so cooked in four batches. By the time the last pieces were done the sauce had separated as others mentioned even though I'd made it just before starting to fry. So if cooking will take a long time, prep the sauce ingredients in the pan and heat only after the last batch is fried. Sauce cooks fast. Otherwise was juicy-n-crispy but will probably up the spices next time.

I failed at this one. All was well and a do again, until the last sauce made with the lard. It came out black and kept separating.We will do it again, but fined a different baste sauce for the end product.

I have made this recipe 5-6 times already. The first time I made a “mistake” and added the dry seasoning to the flour, the second time I followed the recipe exactly and we did not like it as much, so now, my mistake is how we make it.

I follow the recipe except I add 2 TBSP of Harissa to my flour mixture (we really like it hot), and everything else is the same. Harissa is an African spice and I buy the dry powder version. We make this recipe around every 3 weeks as my family cannot go any longer without it.

This recipe is absolutely a standby for us and we will eat it with salad or my son likes it with rice.

I do not work for this spice shop but this is where I buy the Harissa. It is also great on meats and on potatoes.

https://www.savoryspiceshop.com/blends/harissa.html

I have made this several times and it's always a big hit when hosting. When it's just for my little family we take the leftovers and make chicken salad for lunches. As other reviewers have mentioned, I learned after my first time, do not make the sauce too early other wise the spices, butter and lard will separate instead of staying together. It seems to be fickle about how long it can be heated for.

I love hot and spicy food, but the amount of cayenne in the sauce is very overpowering. It also creates a problem in that it soaks up too much of the butter and lard. If I make this again, I'll use 1 tsp of cayenne instead of 2 Tbsp.

I made this today, but since we don't normally keep buttermilk in the house, I used whole milk instead. Other than that, I followed the recipe exactly. The outside of the chicken stayed nice and crunchy, while the inside was tender and juicy. The sauce had a nice kick. I have never had "real" hot chicken from Nashville, but fast food giant Kentucky Fried Chicken (KFC) has been offering it on their menu for a while now, in your choice of either bone-in drumsticks, breasts, and thighs, or Extra-Crispy boneless chicken tenders. However, now that I know I can do it at home, I may go to KFC less often. Thanks

First let me say that while I am from the South, my folks are both transplanted Yankees and know nothing about frying chicken. So I lived in Nashville for a few years and learned a trick or two from some friends' mommas.
Folks, this is the real deal.
Secondly, I hate frying...pan frying, deep frying, you name it, I hate to do it. More specifically, I hate the clean up. This is so worth it.
Thirdly and most importantly, this is not an every day dinner. This is not a once a month dinner. This is a treat and yes, LARD is important.
So, with all that said, I made this with boneless, skin on breasts and thighs cut into some kind of large strips. It was delectable!
For me the heat was spot-on. Sometimes it can be too hot. It was a bit too much for those in my family who are not fans of spice (oh well, more for me, right?), so I do recommend starting with 1 tablespoon of cayenne, as another reviewer said. Thanks, Chef John!

This was my first time attempting fried chicken. I was worried this could come out potentially raw, greasy and stink up my house... neither happened! The chicken was perfectly cooked and the coating was crispy and delicious! I used some leaf lard that I rendered a couple of years ago and had in my freezer, and it found a perfect place in the glaze on this chicken. 

I love that Chef John shows you technique, it makes things easier to visualize and allows you to work things properly. I loved this hot chicken and I will make it as an indulgence here and there! It made for great leftovers the next day, too.
Was really good, very much like KFC recipe. Rate a 4 out of 5

Easy recipe to make. Skin is crispy and the brining made the chicken juicy. I brined for 24 hrs instead of 4-6 hrs.Sauce is tasty,but spicy but great flavor. I would use 1 tbls of cayenne instead of 2,but that's just my preference. I also served the sauce on the side since it was so spicy.
Thermometer is a must to make sure meat is done. 
All in all,a great fried chicken recipe.
The taste was excellent. spicy! Very crispy. Just a lot of work!

I used sweet pickle brine instead of bread and butter pickle brine and Valentina Mexican Hot Sauce instead of Luisiana hot sauce. I also tried this with chicken wings only instead of a whole cut up chicken. It all worked out great!

Just made this, and it turned out great! I usually fail when I try to make fried chicken, it's either soggy or all of the breading just falls off. Like in the video, you can run a fork over it and hear how crunchy it is. The sauce is delicious, just the right amount of heat. I will definitely be making this again, thanks Chef John!
Amazing mix of flavors and awesome crispiness! The glaze has quite the kick!
Butter/lard remained separated from the seasonings & brown sugar, which congealed. Maybe I did something wrong but hard to see how.

My husband and sons love hot food. Me, not as much. I was kind of scared of the amount of cayenne pepper in this recipe but the fats and the brown sugar took the edge off. It was fantastic -- all of us agreed. It was hot but not the kind of hot where you are gulping milk in order to stop crying. It was hot enough for my guys; I wouldn't have wanted it any hotter but I could eat it, too. The techniques here produced juicy and flavorful results. Would definitely make again.

I'm a fried chicken snob, and this recipe came very close to the fiery version I've eaten down South. To turn up the heat, I added a teeny bit of habanero chili powder and that did the trick.

As a seasoned chicken fryer, I also added my not-so-secret ingredient to the flour mixture to make the chicken extra crispy: about a half cup of Matzo meal. Really!

Finally, I have a trusted Lodge cast iron skillet that never lets me down on frying projects. The tricky thing is getting the oil temp just right and keeping it hot. If the oil's not hot enough, it makes for greasy chicken. If it's too hot, the coating burns before the chicken's fully cooked. 

All that sounds like a huge hassle, but it's so incredibly delish, you'll be glad you made the effort!

Very good. Good balance between the spicy sauce and pickles. Tenderizing the chicken with buttermilk made all the difference. Only complaint was it was a little on the greasy side but I'll make it again.
Loved it. Nice and spicy and the pickles are a nice cooling factor.
I live in Nashville and this is the real deal. We don't eat things like this every day, but cowboy up for this real southern traditional meal.
